parts: The Cabeiroi were sometimes depicted as divine craftsmen and sons of this blacksmith god whose love life usually involved getting cheated on by Aphrodite or trying to rape Athena.

Accordingly, one of the Cabeiroi's main cult centers was on this island, where Hephaestus landed after Hera threw him off Olympus. When the Argo visited, it was populated by foul-smelling women who had killed their male relatives and were ruled by Hypsipyle (hip-SIP-uh-lee).
The Cabeiroi were also worshipped in this Aegean island's namesake chthonic "mysteries," which deliberately kept the number, names, and even the genders of its "great gods" a secret.

answers: binding [or government and binding; accept word forms like bound] (That example sentence is from Carnie's introductory book on syntax.)
bilabial [prompt on labial; prompt on lips; do not accept "labiodental"] <Lifshitz>
parts: Name this morphological process, the inflection or variation of verbs to indicate features like tense, number, or person. Latin has four of these verb paradigms; "amō, amās, amat" is from the "first" one.

In the sentence "Heidi bopped herself on the head with a zucchini," "Heidi" and "herself" must refer to the same person, illustrating this syntactic phenomenon whose domain constrains the use of pronouns and anaphors. In the 1980s, Noam Chomsky devised its Principles A, B, and C in a theory of government and this feature.

Both stop consonants in the English word "bop" share all distinctive features except for voicing; that means they have this place of articulation and thus are produced using the same two parts of the mouth as the sound m.

Name this man who offends black students by using the word "spooks" in class, even though he is secretly black himself. After the death of his wife, he has an affair with the college's janitor, Faunia Farley.
Silk appears in The Human Stain, a book by this author of American Pastoral and Portnoy's Complaint.
During The Human Stain, Silk is a neighbor of this character, a recurring protagonist in Roth's books. He narrates American Pastoral and is "Unbound" in the title of a 1981 Roth novel.
The C in ZFC stands for this controversial axiom, which is equivalent to the statement that the Cartesian product of nonempty sets is nonempty.

The axiom of choice is controversial because it permits statements such as the Banach–Tarski paradox, which says that one of these three-dimensional solids can be decomposed into five pieces that can be rearranged into two copies of the original that have the same radius.

ZFC avoids this eponymous paradox by not assuming that the set of all sets exists. That way, the set of sets not containing themselves need not exist, and so one need not worry whether it contains itself.

answers: no deliberate sound [or silence; or tacet; accept any answer indicating no music]
closing the keyboard lid of a piano [accept obvious equivalents; do not accept "opening the keyboard lid"]
I Ching [or Classic of Changes; or Book of Changes] <Cheyne>
parts: Broadly speaking, 4'33" is best known for having this experimental, very minimalist feature.
At the premiere of 4'33", David Tudor marked the beginning of the piece by performing this action.
After 1951, almost all of Cage's work was composed using this text, which he believed helped him to compose using chance.

answers: Alcuin of York [or Ealhwine; or Alhwin; or Alchoin] <Cheyne>
parts: Name this king of Mercia best known for his namesake "Dyke," an earthwork that follows the current border of England and Wales.

Offa quarreled with Jænberht (YANN-bairt), who held this religious position, which is now held by the principal leader of the Church of England. Thomas Becket held this position until his 1170 murder.
Offa was praised by this adviser of Charlemagne, an English scholar who served as the Master of the Palace School of Charlemagne in Aachen.

answers: abusing women [or domestic violence; accept obvious equivalents]
parts: Name this type of action depicted in Donna Ferrato's book of photography Living With the Enemy. It is the subject of a 1994 federal law denounced by some conservatives as a tool to "fill feminist coffers."
The 1994 Violence Against Women Act was introduced by this then-Senator, who remarked in 2016 that if he were still in high school, he would have loved to take Donald Trump "behind the gym."
In the 1986 case Meritor Savings Bank v. Vinson, the Supreme Court determined that sexual harassment violates the Civil Rights Act of this year, in which Lyndon B. Johnson was elected president.

Name this series published alongside essays by Stephen Vincent Benét, Booth Tarkington, and other authors in the Saturday Evening Post. The most enduring image from this series depicts a Thanksgiving dinner.
During World War II, the Office of War Information hired this artist to create the Four Freedoms series, which became some of the many cover illustrations he created for the Saturday Evening Post.
This Jewish artist, whose propaganda posters found less success at the OWI than Rockwell's, earlier painted two anarchists in their coffins in The Passion of Sacco and Vanzetti.
Name this element that forms a room-temperature allotrope made of interconnected 12-atom icosahedra.
The main reason boranes are so electrophilic is because their LUMO is an empty orbital of this type. This type of atomic orbital has an azimuthal quantum number "L" equal to one.
Organoboranes can also be used in this reaction, where their alkyl groups are transmetallated onto a catalyst and coupled to aryl or vinyl halides.

answers: Don Juan [accept Don Juan in Hell; prompt on John] <Droge>
parts: Name this play in which the anarchist Jack Tanner becomes the guardian of a woman referred to as the "Life Force," Ann Whitefield.
This author of Man and Superman described Eliza Doolittle's transformation from a flower girl into a society lady in his play Pygmalion.

The third act of Man and Superman features the actor who plays Jack Tanner also playing this character talking to the Devil. That act is occasionally produced as a separate work titled [this character] in Hell.

answers: Fatimah [accept but DO NOT REVEAL Fatimah bint Muhammad]
Muhammad [prompt on The Prophet; prompt on The Messenger]
parts: Name this wife of Ali who is revered as the "Mother of the Imams" in the Shia religion.
Fatimah is the daughter of this founder of Islam.
This term refers to the family of Muhammad and means "people of the house" in Arabic. Shia Muslims believe that this group is only made up of the so-called "Fourteen Infallibles."

answers: R-nought [or R-sub-zero; or basic reproduction number; or basic reproduction ratio; prompt on partial answers]
SIR model [or susceptible-infected-recovered; or susceptible-infectious-removed; or susceptible-infectious-resistant; accept word forms and alternate combinations]
parts: Identify this quantity that signifies the expected number of people to whom one infected person will directly transmit a disease if the entire population is susceptible. A similar "effective" quantity is used when some of the population is not susceptible.

This compartmental model computes disease propagation using three differential equations that represent disease states over time. An "exposed" state is added to it to make a four-factor version when incubation periods are long.
These biological agents transmit a pathogen from its natural reservoir to a susceptible host without having an immune response. Anopheles mosquitoes act as these agents for malaria.

Name this real-life person that philosopher Robert Nozick used for an argument in which a million people would give 25 cents to watch this man perform. Nozick pointed out that while this man would have more money than others, that would be a just result.
The Wilt Chamberlain example appears in a 1974 book by Nozick titled for "anarchy," "state," and this type of place. It names a Thomas More book.

This hypothetical being described by Nozick derives more of its namesake quantity from resources than others. For example, if this thing eats a cookie, it might earn 100 times more pleasure than an average person.
Name this 1643 victory of the Duc d'Enghien (duke dong-GAN), the Prince of Condé, over Spain, which was fought just days after Louis XIV gained the French throne.
The Battle of Rocroi was fought in the later phase of this war, which was ended by the Peace of Westphalia. Wallenstein and the Count of Tilly fought during this war.

The clash at Rocroi marked the first great defeat of this square Spanish army formation. As an organizational grouping, it featured up to 3,000 soldiers divided into companies, who were divided into 30-soldier units.

answers: Winged Victory of Samothrace [or Nike of Samothrace]
parts: Name this currently headless sculpture in Samothrace depicting the Greek god of victory.
A gilded Nike stands atop an orb on the title figure's hand in this sculptor's Napoleon as Mars the Peacemaker. He also sculpted Psyche Revived by Cupid's Kiss.

Canova's Venus Victrix was commissioned by a member of this family named Camillo and depicts his wife, Pauline Bonaparte. This family's collection included a sculpture of a gladiator with his left arm raised whose pedestal was signed by Agasias.

answers: The Canterbury Tales [or Tales of Caunterbury]
Marguerite of Navarre [or Marguerite of Angouleme; or Margaret of Navarre] <Mehr>
parts: Name this woman who is divorced by Gualtieri but later remarries him and is reunited with her family. She is a symbol of patience in folklore, including a story in The Decameron.
Boccaccio's story of the patient Griselda inspired "The Clerk's Tale," a part of this famed Middle English story collection by Geoffrey Chaucer.
The Decameron also inspired this woman to write a 72-story collection called the Heptameron, which begins with Parlemente and Lady Oisille (wah-ZEE-uh) determining how to entertain stranded guests.
Name this animal shot by the speaker of a Robinson Jeffers poem who also declares, "I'd sooner, except the penalties, kill a man than" one of these animals.
While not born in this state, Jeffers is one of the most well-known poets to reside there. This state is where he constructed his dream house, called Tor House and Hawk Tower.
The beauty of Carmel, California, prompted authors like George Sterling to flock to the region and form a literary colony. Among the colony's residents was this author of The Jungle.

answers: neutrino oscillation [or flavor oscillation; prompt on oscillation]
parts: Name this process in which a certain particle can switch between electron and tau varieties. The probability that the simplest type of this process occurs is proportional to sine-squared of twice the mixing angle.
A neutrino is this type of elementary particle whose wavefunction is antisymmetric under exchange. They have half-integer spin.
The probability of flavor oscillation can be determined from this 3-by-3 matrix. It is unitary in the Standard Model, but it is not necessarily unitary in the seesaw mechanism.

answers: Overseas Collectivity of Saint Pierre and Miquelon [or Collectivité d'Outre-mer de Saint-Pierre-et-Miquelon]
parts: This Middle Eastern country is a member of European sporting associations like UEFA and FIBA Europe. This country was expelled from the Asian Football Confederation after several countries, including Kuwait, refused to play it on the grounds that they did not recognize its independence.

This small island group off the coast of Newfoundland, the last remnant of France's North American colonial empire, uses the euro as their currency despite having boat and air connections only to Canada.
Despite being located entirely in Asia, this country is a member of the Council of Europe. This country fought the Nagorno-Karabakh war with Azerbaijan, and its capital is Yerevan.

answers: Rafael Trujillo [or Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina]
Dominican Republic [or the D.R.; or Republica Dominicana]
Romulo Betancourt [or Romulo Ernesto Betancourt Bello] <Cheyne>
parts: Name this dictator who ordered the assassination of three of the Mirabal sisters who opposed his reign. He was himself killed in 1961 when his Chevrolet was ambushed by assassins near modern-day Santo Domingo.
Trujillo led this Caribbean country that occupies the eastern side of the island of Hispaniola.
In 1960, Trujillo ordered the assassination of this president of Venezuela, who managed to survive a car bombing. This man's determination amid the threats rallied public opinion against Trujillo.

answers: Carlisle Indian Industrial School [or United States Indian Industrial School]
William Frederick "Buffalo Bill" Cody [or Buffalo Bill; prompt on Bill]
parts: Name this institution in Pennsylvania whose attendees were forced to have their hair cut and their names changed. Luther Standing Bear attended here and served as a recruiter.
In 1898, this man and his famous "Wild West" show performed at Carlisle. Annie Oakley was a sharpshooter in this man's stable of performers.
This man was a two-time All-American for Carlisle's football team. He won two Olympic gold medals in track and field in 1912, making him the first American Indian to win a gold medal for the US.
